What Is a Medical Malpractice Lawyer?

A medical malpractice attorney litigates lawsuits on behalf of their clients, who may be a patient or surviving family members of patients. These clients are suing medical practitioners for malpractice.

Malpractice is a word that refers to proficient misconduct on the part of a medical professional or lawyer. In the medical field, it involves the inattentive conduct of the following

  • Doctors
  • Technicians
  • Therapist
  • Dentist
  • Nurses and other medical professionals and healthcare providers.

Medical malpractice cases can occur from surgical errors, birth traumas, medical misdiagnoses, anesthesia errors, irrational delays in treating a diagnosed condition, failure to get informed consent from a patient before treatment and more.

How Medical Malpractice Lawyers Work

This set of lawyers performs many of the day to day tasks of a typically civil litigator. The Civil litigator toil on cases where there’s a legal difference but not implicated with illegal charges. They spend more time interviewing their clients, and as well conducting investigations, drafting motions, developing trial strategies, and litigating cases.

Medical malpractice lawyers also perform additional tasks.

  • They work with medical expert to build up case theories, expert report, and testimony to sustain the plaintiff’s case.
  • They as well take depositions of medical experts, medical personnel, and other third parties
  • The organize gathering and medical records
  • They work hand in hand to set up an independent medical examination(IMES) to acquire an objective evaluation of the injured plaintiff’s condition
  • Performing medical research relating to the plaintiff’s condition
  • Working with legal nurse consultants to analyze case merits, review medical records, and decipher doctor’s notes

Salary Expectations

Since 2019, the median salary of a legal representative was $122,960 per year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The exact salary a medical malpractice attorney earns is different depending on the area of specialization and the number of cases the attorney handle.

The most personal injury lawyers, charges on a contingency fee basis which makes the services of an attorney affordable to those who can’t afford upfront payments. Under a conditional fee arrangement, the lawyer takes a percentage of the plaintiff’s net recovery. While this might sound lucrative, keep in mind that 30 states have a cap on the damages that can be awarded in a medical malpractice suit. This limits the amount you potentially could be paid.

Another aspect that impacts compensation is that more than two-thirds of medical malpractice cases from 2006–2015 cases were dropped, dismissed, or withdrawn, according to a study by the American Medical Association. Another 23% of cases were settled and just 7% were decided by a trial. Out of the 7% of cases that went to trial, 87.5% were won by the defendant (the medical practice or professional) and not the plaintiff

Requirements for a Medical Malpractice Lawyer

To become a MML you must complete the same educational requirements as a lawyer.

Degree Level Juris Doctor
Licensure Must pass bar exam and possibly meet other state requirements for licensure
Experience Experience as an associate before advancing
Key Skills Analysis, critical thinking, research, public speaking, and writing skills
Mean Salary $144,230 (for all lawyers)

How to become a MML

The minimum requirements are as follows;

  • Earn a Bachelor’s Degree
  • Take the LSAT
  • Attend Law School
  • Complete an Internship
  • Take Health or Medical-Related Classes
  • Pass the Bar Exam
  • Prepare for the Bar Exam
  • After the Bar
  • Become Board-Certified

High school Subject Requirements

Below are the lists of subjects to become a MML.

  • English
  • Math Literacy
  • Business studies
  • Accounting
  • Economics
  • A third language
  • Drama
  • Physical science
  • Biology
